In Indiana last week, there was a nuclear attack, not a real one of course, but a mock attack staged by the Indiana National Guard.
And as the disaster unfolded, it demonstrated what many had feared - the National Guard is spread thin fighting overseas and it lacks equipment needed at home.
NPR's Tom Bowman was at the exercise and has this report.
Help me.
Unidentified Man #1: We're coming now, ma'am.
Help me please.
The fire is (unintelligible).

Jackhammers work to free her.
In a tent nearby, the top general in the Indiana National Guard appears before a hastily called mock press conference.
An horrific attack of weapons of mass destruction.
It was a nuclear attack.
Then Major General Martin Umbarger admits that it's all a training exercise.
What they're learning is this: they are short on helicopters, Humvees and trucks.
The Indiana Guard has just 60 percent of its overall equipment.
Part of that is because its soldiers are repeatedly heading to Iraq and Afghanistan.
We have been deployed for the past five years on a pretty constant basis.
